com.gnahraf.io.store.table.iter

Class RowIterator

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gnahraf.io.store.table.iter.RowIterator
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    FilterRowIterator, MergeRowIterator, SortedBufferIterator, TableSetIterator

    public abstract class RowIterator
extends Object
    An directed iterator of fixed-width rows.
    Author:
    Babak

    • Constructor Detail

      • RowIterator

        public RowIterator()

    • Method Detail

      • getDirection

        public abstract Direction getDirection()
        Returns the direction of the iteration. If FORWARD, then successive non-null rows returned by this instance are monotonically increasing; if REVERSE, then successive non-null rows returned by this instance are monotonically decreasing.

      • getRowWidth

        public abstract int getRowWidth()
        Returns the number of bytes in each row.

      • next

        public abstract ByteBuffer next()
                         throws IOException
        Returns the next row, or null if at the end of the iteration. Successive invocations return monotonically increasing or decreasing rows depending on the instance's direction.
        Returns:
        a buffer loaded with the contents of the next row (flipped and ready to read), or null if at the end of the iteration. The returned buffer may be read-only.
        Throws:
        IOException
        See Also:
        next(ByteBuffer)

      • next

        public ByteBuffer next(ByteBuffer buffer)
                throws IOException
        Returns the next row, or null if at the end of the iteration. This method behaves exactly like next() except it uses the given work buffer. Successive invocations return monotonically increasing or decreasing rows depending on the instance's direction.
        Parameters:
        buffer - the buffer the contents of the row is written to. Its capacity must be at least rowWidth bytes.
        Returns:
        the given buffer loaded with the contents of the next row (flipped and ready to read), or null if at the end of the iteration. The base implementation just calls next() and copies the contents into the given buffer. If a subclass can optimize this better, it should.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the capacity of buffer is less than the rowWidth
        IOException
        See Also:
        next()
